blocks.text: The constants, if $A_0$ is already found.
Select two convenient values of the current and work the ordinates of the curve to find $A_1$ and $A_2$; proceed similarly using the two curves to find $A_3$.

Note that in alternating current work only terms of the order of $6$, $5$, $6$ etc., so that the curve would need to be divided into $3$, $2$, etc., as in the parts suppressed. There is thus no reason to mention it, and the constant values of $A_0$ must be more.
The curve ABCD, Fig. 132, gives by its ordinates the displacement of the liquid curve as obtained by a Goodkin Motion.
It is required to find the constants in the equation $y = A_0 + A_1 	ext{sin}(x) + A_2 	ext{sin}(2x) + A_3 	ext{sin}(3x)$.
The origin is divided into two parts, the curve is divided above the first, with the result that Curve 2 is obtained.
The estimated line before this is $B_1$, the height of $B_0$ above the original base line being $29$.

blocks.caption: Fig. 132
blocks.description: The figure illustrates the curve of liquid displacement resulting from a sinusoidal input, highlighting the relationship between current and the resulting wave forms.

blocks.text: The resultant curve is approximately a sine curve symmetrical about the true base line.
